results.title: The Money or the gun = The International year of the patronising bastard (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Mark Fitzgerald, ABC-TV (Australia) and Martin Coombes
results.brief_description: A special episode of “The money or the gun” which looks at the community’s attitudes to the disabled. Andrew Denton interviews members of the public and of the disabled community in an attempt to promote a less patronising approach to the physically handicapped. Also known as “The International Year of the Patronising Bastard”. This program has won international awards.

results.title: The Money game
results.brief_description: Deals with the intricacies and machinations of macro economics, using an economics machine designed by Bruce Petty and actors representing a worker, the government, an employer, a financier, an underdeveloped nation and a foreign investor. Stars Noel Ferrier, Chris Haywood, Alistair Duncan, John Cheoung, Alfred Sandor, Joseph Furst, Nat Leeson. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The money game
results.brief_description:
These days, football clubs are really small businesses, requiring strong financial management in order to survive. From Hepburn to Ouyen, to Swifts Creek, fundraising is an essential part of all footy clubs.

Acknowledgements to Laurince Pedretti, Kate Commins, Derry Monaghan, Ray Gallagher and Tom Greenaway. Archival video and still images reproduced with kind permission of Swifts Creek FNC, Ouyen United FC and Laurince Pedretti.

TRANSCRIPT

[YELL]

[FAINT WHISTLE]

[CHATTER]

[LOUD WHISTLE]

[CHATTER]

BILL PEDRETTI: If you’re going to win premierships, you’ve got to run The Forty Club like a business. And you’ve got to work hard at it. We used to have a lot of fun, but we never won many games.

[HORN BLOWING]

So we turned it around. And that’s why in the last 20 years we’ve won premierships. In the ‘80s, the cash was $2,000. That was big money. And we could rise up with— we took raffles and dinner dances and things like that. And then in the ‘90s when we were just struggling, we realized we had no money. We have to do something better. And that’s when we first started wrestling the Harley Davidsons. Four of the committee rang up together and all put in, and we brought a motorbike. And from then on, it was just full steam ahead.

[MOTOR RUNNING]

KATE COMMINS: I see our biggest challenge as being fundraising, because we have a pretty clear idea of what we are going to get from a go at the Canteen and the bar. And that’s enough to cover our expenses. But it’s not enough to do anything with new buildings. It’s not enough to repair our fairly basic amenities. We can’t send players on trips and things like that. We cannot afford to pay our player’s memberships. We have to ask them to pay, that sort of thing. I’ve really got to watch all the costs.

[CHATTER]

DERRY MONAGHAN: They certainly all pick [INAUDIBLE] stumps. And not for a while they haven’t, but we did that at [INAUDIBLE] just to try and get a couple of extra players each year. And the local boys here cut wood to source money for the football trip.

[CHATTER]

The main source of income is the Vic Grain Bunkers. We have the contract to empty them the [INAUDIBLE] Bunkers. And when we get enough trucks, we can make a lot of money. And that’s how we source the money to run the club. Now it’s one in, all in, and from me, down to the players.

[CHATTER]

KATE COMMINS: Really, the things that keep small country towns going are your pub, your football team, and your primary school. Well, all of those things are kind of in part of our football club. And I think that most people are prepared to come and be part of it, put in that extra bit, do those few extra jobs. Or we might well lose it.

[CROWD CHEERING]

MAN: Everyone on our committee are very successful businessmen in the town in their own right. And they all got kids playing. And that’s where this all stems from. And I think nearly every country footy club would be the same.

results.title: The Money fish
results.creator_credit: Angela Borelli, Two-Up Films, Film Victoria, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Janet McLeod
results.brief_description: Winter in Corner Inlet, Welshpool, Victoria and local commercial fishermen are angry with environmentalists and the Victorian Government who are intent on setting up marine national parks along the Victorian coastline to boost fishing stocks and restrict professional net fishing. Angst also exists between the commercial fishermen and those who practise recreational fishing. For Joe Pizzone, who has given up 26 years of shark fishing in Bass Strait for a new life as an inlet fisherman, owning his own boat and spending more time with his family, the threat of marine parks to his livelihood becomes the new challenge in his life. The documentary follows Joe as he goes about his daily life as a professional fisherman, revealing the harsh conditions, the long hours and the constant battle with the weather, the good days and the bad days and his absolute passion and determination to not just stand by and let bureaucracy and the “greenies” take over without a fight. His loyalty to the community and the local commercial fishing families sees Joe confronting the Environment Conservation Council head-on and taking a pro-active stance in defending the local community’s right to fish and earn a living. This is an interesting film in that it attempts to present all sides of such a vexatious issue, from the commercial fishermen to the proponents of recreational fishing, the Government and the environmentalists. NB: Warning contains some strong language.

results.title: The Mondragon experiment
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
Mondragon in the Basque region of Spain, is an industrial town where more than 80 factories are co-operatively owned by the workers. All this has been created with scant help from a suspicious government and no funds from stock-market investors. It has run successfully for twenty-five years. The workers run the factories and appoint the managers, run their own bank, technical college and research laboratories. In Britain, workers and management have been at loggerheads since the Industrial Revolution. Examines the feasability of Britain following the same road to prosperity. Narrated by Alexander John

results.title: The Moment
results.creator_credit: Apid Busayasiri and Animation and Interactive Media (AIM) RMIT
results.brief_description:
A young man goes to visit the grave of his grandmother at a remote graveyard on the outskirts of a city. While he is there a series of mysterious events unfold that magically transport him back to his joyful childhood. Hand drawn animation.
Graduate work from an AIM (Centre for Animation and Interactive Media) RMIT graduate, 2006.

results.title: The Molluscs
results.creator_credit: Dennis Sawyer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Intertidal Life of the North American Pacific Coast”.
The marine fauna of the British Columbian coast is extremely diverse. The more common animals of the phylum molluscs from the classes Amphineura, Gastropoda, Pelecypoda, Cephalopoda are illustrated. Shows their size, habitat and feeding habits. Industrialisation and pollution have led to the destruction of many molluscs.
